title: α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonists: intraoperative floppy iris syndrome
raw_html:
α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonists: intraoperative floppy iris syndrome

Article date: August 2007
Summary
Cataract surgeons should inquire about past or current use of α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonists for prostatic hypertrophy

Data have accumulated to suggest that intraoperative floppy iris syndrome (IFIS) is a possible class effect of α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonists, which are used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia. IFIS is a newly identified syndrome that can lead to surgical complications during cataract surgery.

An association between IFIS and the α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonist tamsulosin has previously been identified and advice communicated to healthcare professionals.Current Problems in Pharmacovigilance 2006; 31: 6.Letter to healthcare professionals, sent July, 2006. A warning is now being added to the product information for all α-1 adrenoreceptor antagonists, advising patients to inform their cataract surgeon about past or current use of these medicines before surgery to ensure that appropriate measures are in place should IFIS occur.

 

Article citation: Drug Safety Update August 2007; Vol 1, Issue 1: 4-5.
